bestBHT.bht: Joseph of Arimathea, in an act of personal favor, boldly approached Pilate to ask for the body of Jesus. He knew that Jesus was dead and needed to be properly buried, wanting to prevent any mistreatment of the body by the mob or association with the two malefactors.

Philip Schaff: Luke 23:52. See Mark 15:43-45, for the particulars of the request to Pilate.
Archibald T. Robertson: Asked for (ηιτησατο). First aorist middle (indirect) indicative as in Mark 15:43; Matthew 27:58. The middle voice shows that Joseph of Arimathea asked the body of Jesus as a personal favour.
John Gill: Knowing he was dead; that he might bury it.
And prevent its being inferred with the two malefactors, or abused by the mob.

bhtAttempts.bht: Joseph of Arimathea asked for the body of Jesus as a personal favor, going boldly to Pilate and knowing that Jesus was dead and needed to be buried. His request was likely made to prevent the body from being left with the other two malefactors or being abused by the mob.

Joseph of Arimathea, in an act of personal favor, boldly approached Pilate to ask for the body of Jesus. He knew that Jesus was dead and needed to be properly buried, wanting to prevent any mistreatment of the body by the mob or association with the two malefactors.

Joseph of Arimathea, in a personal favor, asked for the body of Jesus, going boldly to Pilate. He knew that Jesus was dead and needed to be buried, preventing any abuse or association with the two malefactors or the mob.

Joseph of Arimathea, in a personal favor, asked for the body of Jesus, going boldly to Pilate. He knew that Jesus was dead and needed to be buried in order to prevent any abuse or association with the two malefactors or the mob.

Joseph of Arimathea asked for the body of Jesus as a personal favor, going boldly to Pilate and knowing that Jesus was dead and needed to be buried. His request was likely made to prevent the body from being left with the other two malefactors or being abused by the mob.
